title: Kamasi Washington takes sax back to the street
text:
"I'm happy for Kamasi, but he doesn't play jazz," Branford Marsalis opined to The Australian Financial Review earlier this year, when asked about the most popular artist to be filed under that category since he and brother Wynton became stars in the 1980s.

When pressed for what kind of music he thought the fellow saxophonist and band leader did play, Marsalis went for "an instrumental version of music that, unlike jazz, most people already like : hip-hop".

Kamasi Washington and his band at the Sydney Opera House on October 9. Daniel Boud

His description felt about right on this night, given the most adventurous hip-hop has itself become a mash-up of genres – funk, soul, Afrobeat, classical and yes, jazz – with Washington blowing sax and arranging strings on the album that's done most to raise the form to that level of sophistication: Kendrick Lamar's To Pimp a Butterfly from 2015.

That credit also raised Washington's subsequent four albums to a streaming count in the tens of millions, unprecedented for music that's at least partly improvised, and the reason he was back on October 9 for his second sold-out show at Sydney Opera House in only 18 months.

With Washington's seven-piece band of childhood friends from Los Angeles including two drummers (Robert Miller Jr and Ronald Bruner Jr), an electric double bass (Miles Mosley) and a Moog synthesiser/keyboard rig (Brandon Coleman), the 38-year-old's sound was never going to have the delicate light and shade of purist jazz from the Marsalis school.
description: Call it jazz, call it hip-hop, but the music of Kendrick Lamar's muse called compellingly to us for most of this Sydney Opera House show.
